verb.description: Shape or force (something straight) into a curve or angle.
examples: the rising wind bent the long grass

verb.description: (of a person) incline the body downward from the vertical.
examples: he bent down and picked her up
he bent to tie his shoelaces

verb.description: Force or be forced to submit.
examples: they want to bend me to their will
a refusal to bend to mob rule

verb.description: Direct or devote (one's attention or energies) to a task.
examples: Eric bent all his efforts to persuading them to donate some blankets
she bent once more to the task of diverting the wedding guests

verb.description: Attach (a sail or rope) by means of a knot.
examples: sailors were bending sails to the spars

noun.description: A curve, especially a sharp one, in a road, river, racecourse, or path.
A curved or angled part or form of something.
examples: making a bend in the wire

noun.description: A kind of knot used to join two ropes, or to tie a rope to another object, e.g. a carrick bend.

proper noun.description: A city in central Oregon; population 77,181 (est. 2008).

phrases: she regularly bent Michael's ear with her problems
Can I bend your ear for a minute about a veterans' issue?
In the following highlights of the day's activities, managers and employees had an opportunity to bend the boss 's ear - and some did.
I've just had Mr Brisedale bending my ear for ten minutes about the quality of my warehouse staff.
I think I've bent your ear enough for today and I have to be at work in an hour.
origin: Late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French bande, Old French bende flat strip.
